physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Ms. A, a 24-year-old woman, presented with a history of severe 2-week premenstrual depressions during the fall and winter months, characterized by fatigue, lethargy, irritability, loss of appetite, insomnia, diurnal variation in mood (worse in the morning), social withdrawal, and suicidal ideas. Her menses occurred regularly approximately every 28 days, with slightly shortened cycles (26 days) in the winter.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Depressive symptoms remitted within a few days after the onset of menses and were absent during the summer.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Baseline Hamilton ratings in the premenstrual phase during a winter month without treatment were 25 and 28; subsequent Hamilton score during the follicular phase was 0.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: In a trial of phototherapy, the Hamilton score decreased drastically from 30 to 10 after 1 week.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: During treatment with light plus placebo, Hamilton score decreased from 25 to 10, and a relapse occurred when melatonin was given with the light (score of 26).
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: When lights and melatonin were discontinued, the Hamilton score returned to the previous level of premenstrual depression (score of 32).

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Propranolol (80mg) reversed the patientâ€™s premenstrual depression (Hamilton score decrease from 25 to 5).
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The 40mg dose was also effective in reducing depressive symptoms (Hamilton score change from 37 to 15).
